When the face of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) became visible to us, we (found) that no sight was more endearing to us than the face of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) as it appeared to us. The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) with the gesture of his hand directed Abu Bakr to step forward (and lead the prayer). The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) then drew the curtain, and we could not see him till he died.
question: What can be inferred about the relationship between the Prophet (ﷺ) and Abu Bakr from this event?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) became ill and illness became serious he ordered Abu Bakr to lead the people in prayer. Upon this 'A'isha said: Messenger of Allah, Abd Bakr is a man of tenderly feelings: when he would stand in your place (he would be so much overwhelmed -by grief that) he would not be able to lead the people in prayer. He (the Holy Prophet) said: You order Abu Bakr to lead the people in prayer, and added: You are like the female companions of Yusuf. So Abu Bakr led the prayer (during this period of illness) in the life of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be learned about the emotional nature of Abu Bakr from this event?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) went to the tribe of Bani Amr b. Auf in order to bring reconciliation amongst (its members), and It was a time of prayer. The Mu'adhdhin came to Abu Bakr and said: Would you lead the prayer in case I recite takbir (tahrima, with which the prayer begins)? He (Abu Bakr) said: Yes. He (the narrator) said: He (Abu Bakr) started (leading) the prayer. The people were engaged in observing prayer when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) happened to come there and made his way (through the people) till he stood in a row. The people began to clap (their hands), but Abu Bakr paid no heed (to it) in prayer. When the people clapped more vigorously, he (Abu Bakr) then paid heed and saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) there. (He was about to withdraw when) the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) signed to him to keep standing at his place. Abu Bakr lifted his hands and praised Allah for what the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had commanded him and then Abu Bakr withdrew himself till he stood in the midst of the row and the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) stepped forward and led the prayer. When (the prayer) was over, he (the Holy Prophet) said: 0 Abu Bakr, what prevented you from standing (at that place) as I ordered you to do? Abu Bakr said: It does not become the son of Abu Quhafa to lead prayer before the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said (to the people) around him: What is it that I saw you clapping so vigorously? (Behold) when anything happens in prayer, say: Subha Allah, for when you would utter it, it would attract the attention, while clapping of hands is meant for women.
question: What is the appropriate way to gain attention during prayer if something unusual occurs?

hadith-eng: " Abu Bakr lifted his hands and praised Allah and retraced his (steps) till he stood in a row."
question: What significance does standing in a row hold in Islamic rituals or gatherings?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) went to Bani Amr b. 'Auf in order to bring about reconciliation amongst them. The rest of the hadith is the same but with (the addition of these words):" The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came and made his way through the rows till he came to the first row and Abu Bakr retraced his steps."
question: What can be learned from the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) approach to maintaining unity among the people?

hadith-eng: I also moved along with him till he came to the people and (he found) that they had been saying their prayer under the Imamah of 'Abd al-Rahman b. 'Auf. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) could get one rak ah out of two and said (this) last rak'ah along with the people. When Abd al-Rahman b. 'Auf pronounced the salutation, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) got up to complete the prayer. This made the Muslims terrified and most of them began to recite the glory of the Lord. When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) finished his prayer, he turned towards them and then said: You did well, or said with a sense of joy: You did the right thing that you said prayer at the appointed hour.
question: What was the reaction of the Muslims when the Prophet (ﷺ) joined the prayer led by 'Abd al-Rahman b. 'Auf?

hadith-eng: I made up my mind to hold Abd al-Rahman b. 'Auf back, but the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Leave him."
question: What lessons can be learned about restraint and patience from the Prophet's (ﷺ) response in this situation?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Glorification of Allah is for men and clapping of hands is meant for women (if something happens in prayer). Harmala added in his narration that Ibn Shihab told him: I saw some of the scholars glorifying Allah and making a gesture.
question: What actions did some scholars take to glorify Allah during prayer according to the narration?

hadith-eng: This hadith is narrated on the authority of Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: How does the chain of transmitters affect the authenticity of a hadith?

hadith-eng: This hadith is transmitted by Muhammad b. Rafi', Abu'I-Razzaq. Ma'mar, Hammam on the authority of Abu Huraira with the addition of (the word)" prayer".
question: What role does Abu Huraira play in the transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: One day the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) led the prayer. Then turning (towards his Companions) he said: O you man, why don't you say your prayer well? Does the observer of prayer not see how he is performing the prayer, for he performs it for himself? By Allah, I see behind me as I see in front of me.
question: What lessons can be learned about self-awareness and personal accountability in performing prayers?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Do you find me seeing towards the Qibla only? By Allah, your bowing and your prostrating are not hidden from my view. Verily I see them behind my back.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's connection with the unseen from this narration?

hadith-eng: Perform bowing and prostration well. By Allah, I see you even if you are behind me, or he said: (I see you) behind my back when you bow or prostrate.
question: What does this narration imply about the Prophet's awareness of his followers' actions during prayer?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said: Complete the bowing and prostration well. By Allah, I see you behind my back as to how you bow and prostrate or when you bow and prostrate.
question: What does this narration imply about the Prophet's knowledge of his followers' actions during prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) one day led us in the prayer. and when he completed the Prayer he turned his face towards us and said: 0 People, I am your Imam, so do not precede me in bowing and prostration and in standing and turning (faces, i. e. In pronouncing salutation), for I see you in front of me and behind me, and then said: By Him in Whose hand Is the life of Muhammad, if you could see what I see, you would have laughed little and wept much more. They said: What did you see, Messenger of Allah? He replied: (I saw) Paradise and Hell.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) describe the impact of witnessing Paradise and Hell on one's emotions?

hadith-eng: This hadith is narrated by Anas with another chain of transmitters, and in the hadith transmitted by Jarir there is no mention of" turning (faces)".
question: What is the role of specific narrators in the transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Does the man who lifts his head ahead of the Imam (from prostration) not fear that Allah may change his head into the head of an ass?
question: What lessons can be learned about discipline and respect in prayer from this teaching?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Does the man who lifts his head before the Imam not fear that Allah may change his face into that of an ass?
question: What does Islamic teaching say about the discipline required in following the Imam's lead in prayer?

hadith-eng: " Allah may make his face like the face of an ass."
question: What lessons can be learned about behavior and its potential outcomes from Islamic narrations?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: The people who lift their eyes towards the sky in Prayer should avoid it or they would lose their eyesight.
question: How does Islamic teaching emphasize the importance of eye positioning during prayer?

hadith-eng: People should avoid lifting their eyes towards the sky while supplicating in prayer, otherwise their eyes would be snatched away.
question: How does Islamic teaching emphasize the importance of focus and humility in prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came to us and said: "How is it that I see you lifting your hands like the tails of headstrong horses? Be calm in prayer." He (the narrator) said: He then again came to us and saw us (sitting) in circles. He said: "How is it that I see you in separate groups?" He (the narrator) said: He again came to us and said: "Why don't you draw yourselves up in rows as angels do in the presence of their Lord?" We said: Messenger of Allah, how do the angels draw themselves up in rows in the presence of their Lord? He (the Holy Prophet) said: "They make the first rows complete and keep close together in the row."
question: How do angels organize themselves in the presence of their Lord according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated by A'mash with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to document the sources and chains of narration in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: When we said prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), we pronounced: Peace be upon you and Mercy of Allah, peace be upon you and Mercy of Allah, and made gesture with the hand on both the sides. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him said: What do you point out with your hands as if they are the tails of headstrong horses? This is enough for you that one should place one's hand on one's thigh and then pronounce salutation upon one's brother on the right side and then on the left.
question: How should one position their hands during the salutation in prayer?

hadith-eng: We said our prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and, while pronouncing salutations, we made gestures with our hands (indicating)" Peace be upon you, peace be upon you." The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) looked towards us and said: Why is it that you make gestures with your hands like the tails of headstrong horses? When any one of you pro- nounces salutation (in prayer) he should only turn his face towards his companion and should not make a gesture with his hand.
question: How should one greet their companions after completing a prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to touch our shoulders in prayer and say: Keep straight, don't be irregular, for there would be dissension in your hearts. Let those of you who are sedate and prudent be near me, then those who are next to them, then those who are next to them. Abu Mas'ud said: Now-a-days there is much dissension amongst you.
question: Who should stand closest to the Imam during congregational prayers and why?

hadith-eng: This hadith is narrated by Ibn Uyaina with the same chain of transmitters.
question: What role does the narrator play in the preservation and transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Let those who are sedate and prudent be near me, then those who are next to them (saying it tliree tinies), and beware of the tumult of the markets.
question: How does the arrangement of people in gatherings reflect their qualities in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Straighten your rows. for the straightening of a row is a part of the perfection of prayer.
question: What is the significance of maintaining order and discipline in congregational prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Complete the rows, for I can see you behind my back.
question: What does the ability of the Prophet (ﷺ) to see behind him indicate about his leadership in prayer?

hadith-eng: This is what was transmitted to us by Abu Huraira from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and, while making a mention of a few ahadith, said: (The Messengerof Allah directed us thus): Establish rows in prayer, for the making of a row (straight) is one of the merits of prayer.
question: What instructions did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) give regarding the arrangement of rows during prayer?

hadith-eng: I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) say: Straighten your rows, or Allah would create dissension amongst you.
question: What are the potential consequences of not aligning rows properly in a congregational setting?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (may peace-be upon him) used to straighten our rows as it lie were straightening an arrow with their help until be saw that we had learnt it from him. One day he came out, stood up (for prayer) and was about to say: Allah is the Greatest, when he saw a man, whose chest was bulging out from the row, so he said: Servants of Allah, you hint straighten your rows or Allah would create dissension amongst you.
question: What actions did the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) take to ensure proper alignment in prayer rows?

hadith-eng: Abu 'Awana reported this hadith with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the sources of hadiths in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: If the people were to know what excellence is there in the Adhan and in the first row, and they could not (get these opportunities) except by drawing lots, they would have definitely done that. And if they were to know what excellence lies in joining the prayer in the first takbir (prayer), they would have vied with one another. And if they were to know what excellence lies in the night prayer and morning prayer, they would have definitely come even if crawling (on their knees).
question: What virtues are associated with the night prayer and morning prayer in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saw (a tendency ) among his Companions to go to the back, so he said to them: Come forward and follow my lead, and let those who come after you follow your lead. People will continue to keep back till Allah will put them at the back.
question: How does the leadership role in prayer influence the behavior of those who follow?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saw people at the end of the mosque, and then the (above-mentioned hadith) was narrated.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) interactions with people in the mosque?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: If you were to know, or if they were to know, what (excellence) lies in the first rows, there would have been drawing of lots (for filling them) ; and Ibn Harb said: For (occupying) the first row there would have been drawing of lots.
question: How does the concept of excellence relate to the arrangement of rows in Islamic congregational prayers?

hadith-eng: The best rows for men are the first rows, and the worst ones the last ones, and the best rows for women are the last ones and the worst ones for them are the first ones.
question: How does the positioning of rows in prayer reflect the principles of modesty and respect in Islam?

hadith-eng: This hadith is narrated by Suhail with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrators for the same hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: I saw men having tied (the ends) of their lower garments around their necks, like children, due to shortage of cloth and offering their prayers behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). One of the proclaimers said: O womenfolk, do not lift your heads till men raise (them).
question: What instructions were given to women during prayer in the presence of men according to this narration?

hadith-eng: When women ask permission for going to the mosque, do not prevent them.
question: What does this narration imply about women's rights to participate in communal prayers?

hadith-eng: I heard Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) say: Don't prevent your women from going to the mosque when they seek your permission. Bilal b. 'Abdullah said: By Allah, we shall certainly prevent them. On this'Abdullah b. Umar turned towards him and reprimanded him to harshly as I had never heard him do before. He ('Abdullah b. Umar) said: I am narrating to you that which comes from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and you (have the audicity) to say: By Allah, we shall certainly prevent them.
question: What can be learned about the importance of adhering to the teachings of the Prophet (ﷺ) from this interaction?

hadith-eng: 'The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Do not prevent the maid-servants of Allah from going to the mosque.
question: What guidance did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) provide regarding women's access to mosques?

hadith-eng: I heard the Messeinger of Allah (ﷺ) say: When your women seek your permission for going to the mosque, you grant them (permission).
question: What are the guidelines for men regarding women's attendance at mosques in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Do not prevent women from going to the mosque at night. A boy said to 'Abdullah b. Umar: We would never let them go out, that they may not be caught in evil. He (the narrator) said: Ibn Umar reprimanded him and said.. I am saying that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said this, but you say: We would not allow!
question: What concerns might arise regarding women attending the mosque at night, and how should they be addressed according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by A'mash with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith?

hadith-eng: Grant permission to women for going to the mosque in the night. His son who was called Waqid said: Then they would make mischief. He (the narrator) said: He thumped his (son's) chest and said: I am narrating to you the hadith of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), and you say: No!
question: What can be inferred about the attitude towards women's participation in religious activities from this narration?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Do not deprive women of their share of the mosques, when they seek permission from you. Bilal said: By Allah, we would certainly prevent them. 'Abdullah said: I say that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said it and you say: We would certainly prevent them!
question: What are the implications of preventing women from attending mosques despite their desire to do so?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: When any one of you (women) participates in the 'Isha' prayer, she should not perfume herself that night.
question: How does the use of perfume relate to the etiquette of attending communal prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to us: When any one of you comes to the mosque, she should not apply perfume.
question: What are the considerations for women in maintaining modesty when going to the mosque?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Whoever (woman) fumigates herself with perfume should not join us in the 'Isha' prayer.
question: What are the implications of wearing perfume for women in the context of Islamic prayer gatherings?

hadith-eng: I heard 'A'isha, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). say: If the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had seen what new things the women have introduced (in their way of life) he would have definitely prevented them from going to the mosque, as the women of BaniIsra'il were prevented.
question: What considerations might be taken into account when determining women's participation in communal prayers?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated by Yahya b. Sa'id with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: The word of (Allah) Great and Glorious: 'And utter not thy prayer loudly, nor be low in it" (xvii. 110) was revealed as the Messenger of Allah (may peace beupon him) was hiding himself in Mecca. When he led his Companions in prayer he raised his voice (while reciting the) Qur'an. And when the polytheists heard that, they reviled the Qur'an and Him Who revealed it and him who brought it. Upon this Allah, the Exalted, said to His Apostle (ﷺ): Utter not thy prayer so loudly that the polytheists may hear thy recitation and (recite it) not so low that it may be inaudible to your Companions. Make them hear the Qur'an, but do not recite it loudly and seek a (middle) way between these. Recite between loud and low tone.
question: What is the significance of finding a balanced approach in reciting the Qur'an during prayer?

hadith-eng: " And utter not thy prayer loudly, not be low in it" (xvii. 110) relate to supplication (du'a').
question: What are the implications of the Quranic verse regarding the loudness of prayer on personal and communal worship?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Hisham with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: " Move not thy tongue therewith" (Ixxv. 16) that when Gabriel brought revelation to him (the Holy Prophet) he moved his tongue and lips (with a view to committing it to memory instantly). This was something hard for him and it was visible (from his face). Then Allah, the Exalted. revealed this a" Move not thy tongue therewith to make haste (in memorising it). Surely on us rests the collecting of it and the reciting of it" (ixxv. 16), i. e. Verily it rests with Us that We would preserve it in your heart and (enable you) to recite it You would recite it when We would recite it and so follow its recitation, and He (Allah) said:" We revealed it, so listen to it attentively. Verily its exposition rests with Us. i. e. We would make it deliver by your tongue." So when Gabriel came to him (to the Holy Prophet), he kept silence, and when he went away he recited as Allah had promised him.
question: What role did Gabriel play in the process of revelation as described in this narration?

hadith-eng: " Do not move thy tongue there with to make haste," that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) felt it hard and he moved his lips. Ibn 'Abbas said to me (Sa'id b. Jubair): I move them just as the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) moved them. Then said Sa'id: I move them just as Ibn 'Abbas moved them, and he moved his lips. Allah, the Exalted, revealed this:" Do not move your tongue therewith to make haste. It is with US that its collection rests and its recital" (al-Qur'an, ixxv. 16). He said: Its preservation in your heart and then your recital. So when We recite it, follow its recital. He said: Listen to it, and be silent and then it rests with Us that you recite it. So when Gabriel came to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), he listened to him attentively, and when Gabriel went away, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) recited as he (Gabriel) had recited it.
question: What role did Angel Gabriel play in the transmission of the Quran to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) neither recited the Qur'an to the Jinn nor did he see them. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) went out with some of his Companions with the intention of going to the bazaar of 'Ukaz And there had been (at that time) obstructions between satans and the news from the Heaven, and there were flung flames upon them. So satan went back to their people and they said: What has happened to you? They said: There have been created obstructions between us and the news from the Heaven. And there have been flung upon us flames. They said: It cannot happen but for some (important) event. So traverse the eastern parts of the earth and the western parts and find out why is it that there have been created obstructions between us and the news from the Heaven. So they went forth and traversed the easts of the earth and its wests. Some of them proceeded towards Tihama and that is a nakhl towards the bazaar of 'Ukaz and he (the Holy Prophet) was leading his Companions in the morning prayer. So when they heard the Qur'an. they listened to it attentively and said: It is this which has caused obstruction between us and news from the Heaven. They went back to their people and said: O our people, we have heard a strange Qur'an which directs us to the right path; so we affirm our faith in it and we would never associate anyone with our Lord. And Allah, the Exalted and Glorious, revealed to His Apostle Muhammad (ﷺ):" It has been revealed to me that a party of Jinn listened to it" (Qur'an, lxxii. 1).
question: What significance does the event of the Jinn listening to the Qur'an hold in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I asked 'Alqama if Ibn Mas'ud was present with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the night of the Jinn (the night when the Prophet met them). He (Ibn Mas'uad) said: No, but we were in the company of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) one night and we missed him. We searched for him in the valleys and the hills and said. He has either been taken away (by jinn) or has been secretly killed. He (the narrator) said. We spent the worst night which people could ever spend. When it was dawn we saw him coming from the side of Hiri'. He (the narrator) reported. We said: Messenger of Allah, we missed you and searched for you, but we could not find you and we spent the worst night which people could ever spend. He (the Holy Prophet) said: There came to me an inviter on behalf of the Jinn and I went along with him and recited to them the Qur'an. He (the narrator) said: He then went along with us and showed us their traces and traces of their embers. They (the Jinn) asked him (the Holy Prophet) about their provision and he said: Every bone on which the name of Allah is recited is your provision. The time it will fall in your hand it would be covered with flesh, and the dung of (the camels) is fodder for your animals. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Don't perform istinja with these (things) for these are the food of your brothers (Jinn).
question: What lessons can be learned from the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) experience with the Jinn regarding the unseen world?

hadith-eng: " The traces of their embers." Sha'bi said: They (the Jinn) asked about their provision, and they were the Jinn of al-jazira, up to the end of the hadith, and the words of Sha'bi have been directly transmitted from the hadith of Abdullah.
question: How are the words of Sha'bi related to the hadith of Abdullah in this narration?

hadith-eng: " The traces of the embers," but he made no mention of what followed afterward.
question: What can be inferred from the omission of certain parts of a hadith in its narration?

hadith-eng: I was not with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) but I wish I were with him.
question: What significance does being in the presence of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) hold for his followers?

hadith-eng: I asked Masruq who informed the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about the night when they heard the Qur'an. He said: Your father, Ibn Mas'ud, narrated it to me that a tree informed him about that.
question: What role did Ibn Mas'ud play in the transmission of knowledge about the Prophet's interactions with the Qur'an?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) led us in prayer and recited in the first two rak'ahs of the noon and afternoon prayers Surat al-Fitiha and two (other) surahs. And he would sometimes recite loud enough for us the verses. He would prolong the first rak'ah more than the second. And he acted similarly in the morning prayer.
question: In what instances did the Prophet recite verses loud enough for the congregation to hear during prayers?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would recite in the first two rak'ahs of the noon and afternoon prayers the opening chapter of the Book and another surah. He would sometimes recite loud enough to make audible to us the verse and would recite in the last two rak'ahs Surat al-Faitiha (only).
question: What is the practice of reciting Surat al-Fatiha in the last two rak'ahs of the noon and afternoon prayers?

hadith-eng:
We used to estimate how long Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) stood in the noon and afternoon prayers, and we estimated hat he stood in the first two rak'ahs of the noon prayer as long as it takes to recite Alif Lam Mim, Tanzil, i. e. as-Sajda. We estimated that he stood half that time in the last two rak'ahs; that he stood in the first two of the afternoon as long as he did in the last two at noon; and in the last two of the afternoon prayer about half that time. 
Abu Bakr in his narration has made no mention of Alif Lam Mim, Tanzil, but said: As long as it takes to recite thirty verses.
question: What significance does the recitation of specific surahs have in determining the length of prayer?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in every rak'ah of the first two rak'ahs of the noon prayer about thirty verses and in the last two about fifteen verses or half (of the first rak'ah) and in every rak'ah of the 'Asr prayer of the first two rak'ahs about fifteen verses and in the last two verses half (of the first ones).
question: How does the recitation of verses differ between the noon and 'Asr prayers according to the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice?

hadith-eng: The people of Kufa complained to Umar b. Khattab about Sa'd and they made a mention of his prayer. 'Umar sent for him. He came to him. He ('Umar) told him that the people had found fault with his prayer. He said: I lead them in prayer in accorance with the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). I make no decrease in it. I make them stand for a longer time in the first two (rak'ahs) and shorten it in the last two. Upon this 'Umar remarked: This is what I deemed of thee, O Abu Ishaq.
question: What was Umar's response to Sa'd's explanation about his prayer leadership?

hadith-eng: This hadith his been narrated by 'Abu al-Malik with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to document the sources and references of hadiths in Islamic literature?

hadith-eng: 'Umar said to Sa'd: They complain against you in every matter, even in prayer. He (Sa'd) said: I prolong (standing) in the first two (rak'ahs) and shorten it in the last two, and I make no negligence in following the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). He ('Umar) remarked: This is what is expected of you, or, that is what I deemed of you.
question: What is the significance of adhering to the prayer practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: " (Sa'd said): These bedouins presume to teach me prayer."
question: What challenges might arise when different groups within a community attempt to teach religious practices to one another?

hadith-eng: The noon prayer would start and one would go to al-Baqi' and after having relieved himself he would perform ablution and then come, while the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would be in the first rak'ah, because he would prolong it so much.
question: What does this narration suggest about the timing and sequence of ablution in relation to prayer?

hadith-eng: I came to Abu Sa'id al-Khudri and he was surrounded by people. When the people departed from him I said: I am not going to ask you what these people have been asking you. I want to ask you about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). He (Abu Sa'id) said: There is no good for you in this. He (Qaz'a), however, repeated (his demand). He then said: The noon prayer would start and one of us would go to Baqi' and, having relieved himself, would come to his home, then perform ablution and go to the mosque, and (he would find) The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) in the first rak'ah.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's prayer routine from this account?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) led us in the morning prayer in Mecca and began Sarat al-Mu'minin (xxiii ) but when he came to the mention of Moses and Aaron (verse. 45) or to the mention of Jesus (verse 50), a cough got the better of him, and he bowed. 'Abdullah b. Sa'ib was present there, and in the hadith narrated by Abd al-Razzaq (the words are): He cut short (the recitation) and bowed.
question: What is the significance of bowing in prayer when recitation is interrupted?

hadith-eng: I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) recite in the morning prayer" Wa'l-lail-i-idhd 'As'asa" (ixxxi. 17).
question: What are the benefits of listening to the recitation of the Quran during prayer?

hadith-eng: I said prayer and the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) led it and he recited" Qaf. (I.). By the Glorious Qur'an," till he recited" and the tall palm trees" (l. 10). I wanted to repeat it but I could not follow its significance.
question: What challenges might a person face in comprehending the deeper meanings of Quranic recitations during prayer?

hadith-eng: " And the tall palm trees having flower spikes piled one above another" (Al-Qur'an 50:10).
question: What is the importance of reciting Quranic verses with specific imagery, such as palm trees, in Islamic prayers?

hadith-eng: "And the tall palm trees having flower spikes piled one above another (l. 10) or perhaps Surah Qaf."
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's (ﷺ) recitation habits during the morning prayer?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in the morning prayer" Qaf. By the Glorious Quran." and his prayer afterward shortened.
question: What are the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regarding the morning prayer?

hadith-eng: He (the Holy Prophet) shortened the prayer and he did not pray like these people then, and he informed me that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite" Qaf. By the (Glorious) Qur'an," and a passage of similar length.
question: How does the prayer practice of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) compare to the practices of people at a later time?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in the noon prayer:" By the night when it envelopes" (xcii.), and in the afternoon like this, but he prolonged the morning prayer as compared to that (noon and afternoon prayers).
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's preference for recitation length in different prayers?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in the noon prayer:" Glorify the name of thy Most High Lord in the morning prayer longer than this" (lxxxvii.)
question: What is the importance of Surah Al-A'la in the context of Islamic prayer rituals?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in the morning prayer from sixty to one hundred verses.
question: How does the recitation length in morning prayer reflect on the practice of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite from sixty to one hundred verses in the morning prayer.
question: How does the length of recitation in prayer reflect on the practice of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: Umm al-Fadl daughter of al-Harith heard him reciting:" By those sent forth to spread goodness" (lxxvii.). (Upon this) she remarked: O my son, you reminded me by the recitation of this surah (the fact) that it was the last surah that I heard from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he recited it in the evening prayer.
question: What is the importance of the evening prayer in Islam?

hadith-eng: " And he did not lead the player after this till his death."
question: What can be inferred about the actions of the Prophet (ﷺ) from the narrations regarding his leadership in prayer?

hadith-eng: I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting Surat al-Tur (Mountain) (lii) in the evening prayer.
question: What is the importance of the evening prayer in Islam and how is it performed?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated by Zuhri with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith?

hadith-eng: I heard al-Bara' narrating it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) that while in a journey he said the night prayer and recited in one of the two rak'ahs:" By the Fig and the Olive" (Su'rah xcv.).
question: What are the benefits of performing night prayers while traveling according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: " By the Fig and the Olive."
question: What is the importance of following the Prophet's example in prayer recitation?

hadith-eng: I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting in the night prayer:" By the Fig and the Olive," and I have never heard anyone with a sweeter voice than he.
question: What is the impact of a melodious voice in the recitation of the Quran during prayers?

hadith-eng: Have you become a hypocrite, so and so? He said: I swear by Allah that I have not, but I will certainly go to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and will inform (him) about this. He then came to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and said: Messenger of Allah, we look after camels used for watering and work by day. Mu'adh said the night prayer with you. He then came and began with Surat al-Baqara. Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) then turned to Mu'adh and said: Are you there to (put the people) to trial? Recite such and recite such (and such a surah). It is transmitted on the authority of Jabir, as told by Sufyan, that he (the Holy Prophet) had said: "By the sun and its morning brightness" (Surah xci), "By brightness" (Surah xciii), "By the night when it spreads" (Surah xcii), and "Glorify the name of thy most high Lord" (Surah lxxxii).
question: What guidance did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) provide regarding the selection of Surahs for prayer recitation?

hadith-eng: 'Mu'adh b. Jabal al-Ansari led his companions in the night prayer and prolonged it for them. A person amongst us said prayer (after having separated himself from the congregation). Mu'adh was informed of this, and he remarked that he was a hypocrite. When it (the remark) was conveyed to the man, he went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and informed him of what Mu'adh had said. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to him: Mu'adh, do you want to become a person putting (people) to trial? When you lead people in prayer, recite:" By the Sun and its morning brightness" (Surat ash-Shams)," Glorify the name of thy most high Lord" (Surat al-A`la) and" Read in the name of Lord" (Surat al-`Alaq), and" By the night when it spreads" (Surat al-Lail).
question: What are some recommended Surahs to recite during prayer as mentioned in the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: Mu'adh b. Jabal said the night prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and then returned to his people and then led them in this prayer.
question: What can be learned from the actions of Mu'adh b. Jabal regarding communal prayer leadership?

hadith-eng: Mu'adh said the night prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). He then came to the mosque of his people and led them in prayer.
question: What can be learned about the practice of leading multiple prayer congregations from this narration?

hadith-eng: A person came to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and said: I keep away from the morning prayer on account of such and such (a man), because; he keeps us so long. I never saw God's Messenger (ﷺ) more angry when giving an exhortation than he was that day. He said: 0 people, some of you are scaring people away. So whoever of you leads the people in prayer he must be brief, for behind him are the weak, the aged, and the people who have (argent) business to attend.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) react to complaints about lengthy prayers, and what lesson can be learned from his response?

hadith-eng: This hadith like one narrated by Hashalm has been narrated from Isma'il with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to compare different narrations of the same hadith?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said: When any one of you leads the people in prayer, he should be brief for among them are the young and the aged, the weak and the sick. But when one of you prays by himself, he may (prolong) as he likes.
question: What flexibility does an individual have in the length of their personal prayers compared to leading a group?

hadith-eng: This is what Abu Huraira transmitted to us from Muhammad the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), and he narrated (some) ahadith out of (these narrations and one of them is this): The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: When any one of you stands to lead people In prayer, he should shorten it, for amongst them are the aged, and amongst them are the weak, but when he prays by himself, he may prolong his prayer as he likes.
question: What is the guidance for someone praying alone in terms of the length of their prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: When any one of you leads people in prayer, he must shorten it for among them are the weak, the infirm and those who have business to attend.
question: How does accommodating the needs of the congregation reflect the principles of compassion and understanding in Islam?

hadith-eng: Abu Bakr b. 'Abd al-Rahman reported that he had heard Abu Huraira say that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said like it, but he substituted" the aged" for 'the infirm".
question: Why might different narrators use slightly different terms when recounting the same hadith?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said to him: Lead your people in prayer. I said: Messenger of Allah. I perceive something (disturbing) in my soul. He (the Holy Prophet) asked me to draw near him and making me sit down in front of him he placed his hand on my breast between my nipples. and then, telling me to turn round, he placed it on my back between my shoulders. He then said: Act as an Imam for your people. He who acts as Imam of the people, he must be brief, for among them are the aged, among them are the sick, among them are the weak, and among them are the people who have business to attend. But when any of you prays alone, he may pray as he likes.
question: What is the significance of being brief in congregational prayers according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The last thing which the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) instructed me was: When you lead the people in prayer, be brief.
question: How can a leader ensure they are considerate of the congregation's needs during prayer?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to be brief and perfect in prayer.
question: What can be learned about the balance between brevity and thoroughness in religious practices from the Prophet's example?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was among those whose prayers was brief and perfect.
question: What lessons can be learned from the Prophet's (ﷺ) approach to prayer in terms of quality and duration?

hadith-eng: I never prayed behind an Imam who was more brief and more perfect in prayer than the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What are the characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) leadership in prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would listen to the crying of a lad in the company of his mother, in prayer, and he would recite a short surah or a small surah.
question: How does the Prophet's (ﷺ) behavior in prayer reflect his compassion and understanding towards his followers?

hadith-eng: When I begin the prayer I Intend to make it long, but I hear a boy cry. ing; I then shorten it because of his mother's feelings.
question: How does the crying of a child influence the conduct of prayer in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I noticed the prayer of Muhammad (ﷺ) and saw his Qiyam (standing), his bowing, and then going back to the standing posture after bowing, his prostration, his sitting between the two prostrations, and his prostration and sitting between salutation and going away, all these were nearly equal to one another.
question: What is the importance of maintaining balance and equality in the different positions of prayer?

hadith-eng: There dominated in Kufa a man whose name was men- tioned as Zaman b. al-Ash'ath, who ordered Abu 'Ubaidah b. 'Abdullah to lead people in prayer and he accordingly used to lead them. Whenever he raised his head after bowing, he stood up equal to the time that I can recite (this supplication): O Allah! our Lord! unto Thee be the praise which would fill the heavens and the earth, and that which will please Thee besides them I Worthy art Thou of all praise and glory. None can prevent that which Thou bestowest, and none can bestow that whichthou preventest. And the greatness of the great will not avail him against Thee. Hakam (the narrator) said: I made a mention of that to Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Laila who reported: I heard al-Bara' b. 'Azib say that the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and his bowing, and when he lifted his head from bowing, and his prostration, and between the two prostrations (all these acts) were nearly proportionate. I made a mention of that to 'Ar b. Murrah and he said: I saw Ibn Abi Laili (saying the prayer), but his prayer was not like this.
question: What can be learned from the differences in prayer practices among early Muslims?

hadith-eng: When Matar b. Najiya dominated Kufa he ordered Abu Ubaida to lead people in prayer, and the rest of the hadith is the same.
question: What are the responsibilities of an appointed leader in conducting prayers?

hadith-eng: While leading you in prayer I do not shorten anything in the prayer. I pray as I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) leading us. He (Thabit) said: Anas used to do that which I do not see you doing; when he lifted his head from bowing he stood up (so long) that one would say: He has forgotten (to baw down in prostration). And when he lifted his head from prostration, he stayed in that position, till someone would say: He has forgotten (to bow down in prostration for the second sajda).
question: What can be inferred about the importance of patience and attentiveness in prayer from this practice?

hadith-eng: I have never said such a light and perfect prayer as I said behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). The prayer of the Messenger. of Allah (ﷺ) was well balanced. And so too was the prayer of Abu Bakr well balanced. When it was the time of 'Umar b. al-Khattab he prolonged the morning prayer. When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Allah listened to him who praised Him, he stood erect till we said: He has forgotten. He then prostrated and sat between two prostration till we said: He has forgotten.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perceive changes in prayer practices over time?

hadith-eng: They used to say prayer behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). I never saw anyone bending his back at the time when he (the Holy Prophet) raised his head, till the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) placed his forehead on the ground. They then fell in prostration after him.
question: What can be learned about the timing of movements in congregational prayer from this account?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Allah listened to him who praised Him, none of us bent his back till he (the Holy Prophet) prostrated; we then, afterwards, went down in prostration.
question: What does this narration imply about the timing of prostration in prayer?

hadith-eng: They (the Companions) said prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), and they bowed when he (the Holy Prophet) bowed. and when he raised his head after bowing, he pronounced:" Allah listened to him who praised Him," and we kept standing till we saw him placing his face on the ground and then we followed him.
question: What does the phrase 'Allah listened to him who praised Him' signify in the context of prayer?

hadith-eng: When we were (in prayer) with the Messenger of Allah Allah (ﷺ) none of us benfft his back till we saw he prostrated. Zuhair and others reported:" till we saw him prostrating".
question: What does this narration teach about the discipline and attentiveness required in congregational prayer?

hadith-eng: I said the dawn prayer behind the Apostle of (ﷺ) and heard him reciting: 'Nay. I call to witness the stars, running their courses and setting" (al-Qur'an, lxxxi. 15-16) and Done of us bent his back till he completed prostration.
question: What is the importance of maintaining proper posture during prayer according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) raised his back from the rukd' he pronounced: Allah listened to him who praised Him. O Allah! our Lord! unto Thee be praise that would fill the heavens and the earth and fill that which will please Thee besides them.
question: What are the phrases used to praise Allah that are mentioned in this context?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite this supplication: O Allah! our Lord, unto Thee be praise that would fill the heavens and the earth and fill that which will please Thee besides them.
question: What are the benefits of reciting supplications that emphasize the vastness of Allah's praise?

hadith-eng: O Allah! our Lord, unto Thee be praise that would fill the heavens and the earth and fill that which will please Thee besides (them). O Allah! purify me with snow, (water of) hail and with cold water; O Allah. cleanse me from the sins and errors just as a white garment is cleansed from dirt.
question: What is the importance of seeking purification from sins in Islamic supplications?

hadith-eng: " just as the white garment is cleansed from filth," and in the narration of Yazid:" from dirt".
question: How do different narrations of a hadith contribute to the understanding of its meaning?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) raised his head after bowing, he said: O Allah! our Lord, to Thee be the praise that would fill all the heavens and the earth, and all that it pleases Thee besides (them). O, thou art worthy of praise and glory, most worthy of what a servant says, and we all are Thy servants, no one can withhold what Thou givest or give what Thou withholdest, and riches cannot avail a wealthy person against Thee.
question: What does it mean for a servant to acknowledge their servitude to Allah in their supplications?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) raised his head after bowing, he said: Allah! our Lord, to Thee be the praise that would fill the heavens and the earth and that which is between them, and that which will please Thee besides (them). Worthy art Thou of all praise and glory. No one can withhold what Thou givest, or give what Thou withholdest. And the greatness O! the great availeth not against Thee.
question: What does the phrase 'the greatness O! the great availeth not against Thee' imply about Allah's power and authority?

hadith-eng: " And that would fill that which will please Thee besides (them)!" and he did not mention the subsequent (portion of supplication).
question: What is the role of specific phrases or words in enhancing the effectiveness of a supplication?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) drew aside the curtain (of his apartment) and (he saw) people in rows (saying prayer) behind Aba Bakr. And he said: Nothing remains of the glad tidings of apostlehood, except good visions which a Muslim sees or someone is made to see for him. And see that I have been forbidden to recite the Qur'an in the state of bowing and prostration. So far as Ruk'u is concerned, extol in it the Great and Glorious Lord, and while prostrating yourselves be earnest in supplication, for it is fitting that your supplications should be answered.
question: How should a Muslim engage in supplication during prostration in prayer to ensure their prayers are answered?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) drew aside the curtain and his head was bandaged on account of illness in which he died. He said: O Allah, have I not delivered (Thy Message)? (He repeated it) three times. Nothing has been left out of the glad tidings of apostlebood, but good vision. which a pious servant (of Allah) sees or someone else is made to see for him. He then narrated like the hadith transmitted by Sufyan.
question: What role does a pious servant play in receiving or witnessing good visions according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) forbade me to recite (the Qur'an) in a state of bowing and prostration.
question: What instructions did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) give regarding the recitation of the Qur'an during specific parts of the prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) forbade to recite the Qur'an, while I am in the state of bowing and prostration.
question: What actions are prohibited during bowing and prostration in Islamic prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) forbade me from the recitation (of the Qur'an) in bowing and prostration and I do not say that he forbade you.
question: How does the guidance of the Prophet (ﷺ) influence individual practices in prayer?

hadith-eng: My loved one (the Holy Prophet) forbade me that I should recite (the Qur'an) in a state of bowing and prostration.
question: How does the guidance on recitation during prayer reflect the etiquette of worship in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) forbade me to recite the Qur'an while I am in a state of bowing and prostration, and in their narration (there is a mention of) forbiddance from that (recital) in the state of prostration as it has been transmitted by Zuhri, Zaid b. Aslam, al-Wahid b. Kathir, and Dawud b. Qais.
question: What are the implications of the prohibition of Qur'anic recitation during specific parts of the prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith is transmitted on the authority of 'Ali, but he made no mention of" while in prostration".
question: What are the implications of variations in hadith narrations on Islamic jurisprudence?

hadith-eng: I was forbidden to recite (the Qur'an) while I was bowing, and there is no mention of 'Ali in the chain of transmitters.
question: How does the absence of a specific narrator in the chain affect the understanding of a hadith?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: The nearest a servant comes to his Lord is when he is prostrating himself, so make supplication (in this state).
question: How does the act of prostration enhance a servant's relationship with their Lord?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to say while prostrating himself: O Lord, forgive me all my sins, small and great, first and last, open and secret.
question: Why is it important to ask for forgiveness for both open and secret sins?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him') often said while bowing and prostrating himself:" Glory be to Thee, O Allah, our Lord, and praise be to Thee, O Allah, forgive me," thus complying with the (command in) the Qur'an.
question: What is the significance of glorifying and praising Allah during the acts of bowing and prostration in Islamic prayer?

hadith-eng: Hallowed be Thou, and with Thy praise, I seek forgiveness from Thee and return to Thee. She reported: I said: Messenger of Allah, what are these words that I find you reciting? He said: There has been made a sign for me in my Ummah; when I saw that, I uttered them (these words of glorification for Allah), and the sign is:" When Allah's help and victory..... to the end of the surah.
question: What is the importance of glorifying Allah and seeking His forgiveness in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: Never did I, see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) after the revelation (of these verses):" When Allah's help and victory came." observin- his prayer without making (this supplication) or he said in it (supplication): Hallowed be Thee, my Lord, and with Thy praise, O Allah, forgive me.
question: What is the significance of seeking forgiveness in the prayers of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) recited often these words: Hallowed be Allah and with His praise, I seek the forgiveness of Allah and return to Him. She said: I asked: Messenger of Allah, I see that you often repeat the saying" subhan allahi bihamdihi astag firullahi watubuilaih" whereupon he said: My Lord informed me that I would soon see a sign in my Ummah, so when I see it I often recite (these) words: Hallowed be Allah and with His Praise, I seek forgiveness of Allah and return to Him. Indeed I saw it (when this verse) was revealed:" When Allah's help and victory came, it marked the victory of Mecca, and you see people entering into Allah's religion in troops, celebrate the praise of Thy Lord and ask His forgiveness. Surely He is ever returning to Mercy."
question: What is the connection between the victory of Mecca and the command to praise and seek forgiveness from Allah?

hadith-eng: I asked 'Ata': What do you recite when you are in a state of bowing (in prayer)? He said:" Hallowed be Thou, and with Thy praise, there is no god but Thou." Son of Abd Mulaika narrated to me on the anthority of 'A'isha (who reported): I missed one night the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) (from his bed). I thought that he might have gone to one of his other wives. I searched for him and then came back and (found him) in a state of bowing, or prostration, saying: Hallowed be Thou and with Thy praise; there is no god but Thou. I said: With my father mayest thou be ransomed and with my mother. I was thinking of (another) affair, whereas you are (occupied) in another one.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) dedication to prayer from this narration?

hadith-eng: One night I missed Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) from the bed, and when I sought him my hand touched the soles of his feet while he was in the state of prostration; they (feet) were raised and he was saying:" O Allah, I seek refuge in Thy pleasure from Thy anger, and in Thy forgiveness from Thy punishment, and I seek refuge in Thee from Thee (Thy anger). I cannot reckon Thy praise. Thou art as Thou hast lauded Thyself."
question: What does this narration teach about seeking refuge in Allah's attributes during prayer?

hadith-eng: All Glorious, All Holy, Lord of the Angels and the Spirit.
question: What significance do the angels and the Spirit hold in the context of Islamic prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated on the authority of 'A'isha by another chain of transmitters.
question: What role does 'A'isha play in the transmission of hadiths in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: I met Thauban, the freed slave. of Allah's Messenger (ﷺ), and asked him to tell me about an act for which, if I do it, Allah will admit me to Paradise, or I asked about the act which was loved most by Allah. He gave no reply. I again asked and he gave no reply. I asked him for the third time, and he said: I asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) about that and he said: Make frequent prostrations before Allah, for you will not make one prostration without raising you a degree because of it, and removing a sin from you, because of it. Ma'dan said that then lie met Abu al-Darda' and when he asked him, he received a reply similar to that given by Thauban.
question: What actions are considered most beloved to Allah that can lead a believer to Paradise?

hadith-eng: I was with Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) one night. and I brought him water and what he required. He said to me: Ask (anything you like). I said: I ask your company in Paradise. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Or anything else besides it. I said: That is all (what I require). He said: Then help me to achieve this for you by devoting yourself often to prostration.
question: What does this narration suggest about the relationship between personal desires and spiritual practices?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) had been commanded that he should prostrate on the seven (bones) and he was forbidden to fold back the hair and clothing. And in the narration transmitted by Abu Rabi' (the words are):" on the seven bones and I was forbidden to fold back the hair and clothing". According to Abu'l-Rabi' (the seven bones are): The hands, the knees, and the (extremities) of the feet and the forehead.
question: What is the significance of prostrating on specific body parts in Islamic prayer?

hadith-eng: I was commanded to prostrate myself on seven bones and not to fold back clothing or hair.
question: How does the physical posture in prayer reflect obedience to divine commands?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had been commanded to prostrate on seven (bones) and forbidden to fold back hair and clothing.
question: How does the physical posture in prayer reflect obedience to divine commands?

hadith-eng: I have been commanded to prostrate myself on seven bones:" forehead," and then pointed with his hand towards his nose, hands, feet, and the extremities of the feet; and we were forbidden to fold back clothing and hair.
question: How does the physical act of prostration relate to the spiritual aspects of prayer in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: I was commanded to prostrate myself on the seven (bones) and forbidden to fold back hair and clothing. (The seven bones are): forehead, nose, hands, knees and feet.
question: How does the physical act of prostration reflect submission in Islamic prayer?

hadith-eng: "When a person prostates, he prostates on seven part of the body: His face, his hands, his knees and his feet."
question: How does the correct posture in prostration reflect the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: Why is it that you touched my head? He (Ibn 'Abbas) replied: (The man who observes prayer with plaited hair) is like one who prays with his hands tied behind.
question: What are the implications of comparing plaited hair during prayer to having hands tied behind the back?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Observe moderation in prostration, and let none of you stretch out his forearms (on the ground) like a dog.
question: How does moderation in prostration reflect the overall discipline required in Islamic prayer?

hadith-eng: " None of you should stretch out his forearms like the stretching out of a dog."
question: What are the guidelines for maintaining dignity and respect in prayer according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said. When you prostrate yourself, place the palms of your hands on the ground and raise your elbows.
question: What are the specific instructions given by the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regarding the posture in sujood?

hadith-eng: When the Prophet (ﷺ) prostrated, lie spread out his arms so that the whiteness of his armpits was visible.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's physical actions during sujood in terms of prayer etiquette?

hadith-eng: " When the Messenger of Allah (rtiay peace be upon him) prostrated, he spread out his arms so that the whiteness of his armpits was visible." And in the narration transmitted by al-Laith (the words are:" When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prostrated. he spread his hands from the armpits so that I saw their whiteness."
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's manner of prostration regarding the practice of prayer?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prostrated himself, if a lamb wanted to pass between his arms, it could pass.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) physical movements during prayer from the description of his prostration?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prostrated himself, he spread his arms, i. e. he separated them so much that the whiteness of his armpits became visible from behind and when he sat (for Jalsa) he rested on his left thigh.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of resting on his left thigh during Jalsa?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prostrated, he kept his hands so much apart from each other that when it was seen from behind the armpits became visible. Waki' said: That is their whiteness.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer from the visibility of his armpits during prostration?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to begin prayer with takbir (saying Allahu Akbar) and the recitation: "Praise be to Allah, the Lord of the Universe." When he bowed he neither kept his head up nor bent it down, but kept it between these extremes; when he raised his head after bowing he did not prostrate himself till he had stood erect; when he raised his head after prostration he did not prostrate himself again till he sat up. At the end of every two rak'ahs he recited the tahiyya; and he used to place his left foot flat (on the ground) and raise up the right; he prohibited the devil's way of sitting on the heels, and he forbade people to spread out their arms like a wild beast. And he used to finish the prayer with the taslim.
question: What is the significance of the tahiyya and taslim in the prayer according to the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: When one of you places in front of him so me. thing such as the back of a saddle, he should pray without caring who passes on the other side of it.
question: What are the guidelines for ensuring one's prayer is not disturbed by passersby?

hadith-eng: We used to say prayer and the animals moved in front of us. We mentioned it to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he said: If anything equal to the back of a saddle is in front of you, then what walks in front, no harm would come to him. Ibn Numair said: No harm would come whosoever walks in front.
question: What guidance did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) provide regarding distractions during prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was asked about sutra of a worshipper; he said: Equal to the back of the saddle.
question: How does the use of a sutra affect the validity or focus of a prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was asked in the expedition of Tabuk about the sutra the worshipper; he said: Like the back of the saddle.
question: Why was the sutra discussed during the expedition of Tabuk?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) went out on the 'Id day, he ordered to carry a spear-and it was fixed in front of him, and he said prayer towards its (direction), and the people were behind him. And he did it in the journey, and that is the reason why the Amirs carried it.
question: Why do leaders or Amirs carry a spear during journeys according to Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) set up (sutra), and Abu Bakr said: He implanted iron-tipped spear and said prayer towards its direction. Ibn Abu Shaiba made this addition to it:" Ubaidullah said that it was a spear."
question: What materials can be used as a sutra according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to place his camel (towards the Ka'ba) and said prayer in its direction.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practices regarding prayer while traveling?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to say prayer towards his camel. Ibn Numair said: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said prayer towards the camel.
question: What can be inferred about the permissibility of using animals as a sutrah during prayer?

hadith-eng: I came to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) in Mecca and he was (at that time) at al- Abtah in a red leather tent. And Bilal stepped out with ablution water for him. (And what was left out of that water) some of them got it (whereas others could not get it) and (those who got it) rubbed themselves with it. Then the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) stepped out with a red mantle on him and I was catching a glimpse of the whiteness of his shanks. The narrator said: He (the Holy Prophet) performed the ablution. and Bilal pronounced Adhan and I followed his mouth (as he turned) this side and that as he said on the right and the left:" Come to prayer, come to success." ' A spear was then fixed for him (on the ground). He stepped forward and said two rak'ahs of Zuhr, while there passed in front of him a donkey and a dog, and these were not checked. He then said two rak'ahs of the 'Asr prayer, and he then continued saying two rak'ahs till he came back to Medina.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of performing two rak'ahs of prayer in different locations?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) (in Mecca at al-Abtah) in a red leather tent. and I saw Bilal take the ablution water (left by Allah's Messenger), and I saw the people racing, with one another to get that ablution water. If anyone got some of it, he rubbed himself with it, and anyone who did not get any got some of the moisture from his companion's hand. I then saw Bilal take a staff and fix it in the ground, after which the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came out quickly in a red mantle and led the people in two rak'ahs facing the staff, and I saw people and animals passing in front of the staff.
question: What does the behavior of the companions in seeking the Prophet's ablution water indicate about their reverence for him?

hadith-eng: Some of them tried to excel the others (in obtaining water), and in the hadith transmitted by Malik b. Mighwal (the words are): When it was noon, Bilal came out and summoned (people) to (noon) prayer.
question: What role did Bilal play in the Islamic community during the time of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) went at noon towards al-Batha', he performed ablution, and said two rak'ahs of the Zuhr prayer and two of the 'Asr prayer, and there was a spear in front of him. Shu'ba said and Aun made this addition to it on the authority of his father Abu Juhaifa: And the woman and the donkey passed behind it.
question: What is the ruling on people or animals passing in front of someone who is praying?

hadith-eng: The people began to get water that was left out of his (the Prophet's) ablution.
question: What can be inferred about the blessings associated with the Prophet's actions from this event?

hadith-eng: I came riding on a she-ass, and I was on the threshold of maturity, and the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was leading people in prayer at Mina. I passed in front of the row and got down, and sent the she-ass for grazing and joined the row, and nobody made any objection to it.
question: What does this event suggest about the presence of animals near prayer areas in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: The donkey passed in front of the row and then he got down from it And joined the row along with the people.
question: What are the etiquettes of moving in front of a prayer row during Salah?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) was leading prayer at 'Arafa.
question: What are the key elements of prayer during significant Islamic gatherings or events?

hadith-eng: It was in the Farewell Pilgrimage or on the Day of Victory.
question: What is the importance of chain of transmitters in the authentication of hadiths?

hadith-eng: When any one of you prays he should not let anyone pass in front of him (if there is no sutra), and should try to turn him away as far as possible, but if he refuses to go, he should turn him away forcibly for he is a devil.
question: How should one react if someone insists on passing in front of them during prayer?

hadith-eng: I narrate to you what I heard and saw from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: One day I was with Abu Sa'id and he was saying prayer on Friday turning to a thing which concealed him from the people when a young man from Banu Mu'ait came there and he tried to pass in front of him; he turned him back by striking his chest. He looked about but finding no other way to pass except in front of Abu Sa'id, made a second attempt. He (Abu Sa'id) turned him away by Striking his chest more vigorously than the first stroke. He stood up and had a scuffle with Abu Sa'id. Then the people gathered there He came out and went to Marwan and complained to him what had happened to him. Abu Sa'id too came to Marwan. Marwin said to him: What has happened to you and the son of your brother that he came to complain against you? Abu Sa'id said: I heard from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: When any one of you prays facing something which conceals him from people and anyone tries to pass in front of him, he should be turned away, but if he refuses, he should be forcibly restrained from it, for he is a devil.
question: How should conflicts be resolved when someone interrupts a person during prayer?

hadith-eng: When any one of you prays, he should not allow anyone to pass before him, and if he refuses, he should be then forcibly resisted, for there is a devil with him.
question: How is the presence of a devil associated with someone passing in front of a person during prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated by Ibn Umar by another chain of transmitters.
question: What is the role of Sahih Muslim in the compilation and preservation of hadiths?

hadith-eng: If anyone who passes in front of a man who is praying knew the responsibility he incurs, he would stand still forty (years) rather than to pass in front of him Abu Nadr said: I do not know whether he said forty days or months or years.
question: How does Islamic teaching emphasize the respect for the act of prayer and the space of the worshipper?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated from Abu Juhaim Ansari by another chain of transmitters.
question: How does the chain of transmitters affect the authenticity of a hadith?

hadith-eng: Between the place of worship where the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prayed and the wall, there was a gap through which a goat could pass.
question: What significance does the gap between the prayer area and the wall hold in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: He sought the place (in the mosque) where the copies of the Qur'an were kept and glorified Allah there, and the narrator made a mention that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) sought that place and that was between the pulpit and the qibla-a place where a goat could pass.
question: How does the physical arrangement of a mosque influence the practices and rituals performed within it?

hadith-eng: Salama sought to say prayer near the pillar which was by that place where copies of the Qur'an were kept. I said to him: Abu Muslim. I see you striving to offer your prayer by this pillar. He said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) seeking to pray by its side.
question: How can the placement of religious texts influence the choice of prayer location in a mosque?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of 'Allah (ﷺ) said: When any one of you stands for prayer and there is a thing before him equal to the back of the saddle that covers him and in case there is not before him (a thing) equal to the back of the saddle, his prayer would be cut off by (passing of an) ass, woman, and black Dog. I said: O Abu Dharr, what feature is there in a black dog which distinguish it from the red dog and the yellow dog? He said: O, son of my brother, I asked the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) as you are asking me, and he said: The black dog is a devil.
question: Why is the black dog specifically mentioned as having a negative impact on prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by Humaid b. Hilal on the authority of Yunus.
question: How is the authenticity of a hadith determined through its narrators?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: A woman, an ass and a dog disrupt the prayer, but something like the back of a saddle guards against that.
question: How does the presence of certain elements affect the validity of a prayer?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) used to pray at night while I lay interposed between him and the Qibla like a corpse on the bier.
question: What can be inferred about the relationship between the Prophet and 'A'isha from this narration?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said his whole prayer (Tahajjud prayer) during the night while I lay between him and the Qibla. When he intended to say Witr (prayer) he awakened me and I too said witr (prayer).
question: What is the role of the Witr prayer in the nightly prayers of a Muslim?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha asked: What disrupts the prayer? We said: The woman and the ass. Upon this she remarked: Is the woman an ugly animal? I lay in front of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) like the bier of a corpse and he said prayer.
question: What does the hadith imply about the presence of women during prayer?

hadith-eng: It was mentioned before'A'isha that prayer is invalidated (in case of passing) of a dog, an ass and a woman (before the worshipper, when he is not screened). Upon this 'A'isha said: You likened us to the asses and the dogs. By Allah I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying prayer while I lay on the bedstead interposing between him and the Qibla. When I felt the need, I did not like to wit to front (of the Holy Prophet) and perturb the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and quietly moved out from under its (i. e. of the bedstead) legs.
question: What are the views on what can invalidate a prayer according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: You have made us equal to the dogs and the asses, whereas I lay on the bedstead and the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came there and stood in the middle of the bedstead and said prayer. I did not like to take off the quilt from me (in that state), so I moved away quietly from the front legs of the bedstead and thus came out of the quilt.
question: What can be inferred about the spatial arrangements and considerations during the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer from this narration?

hadith-eng: I was sleeping in front of the Mcsseinger ef Allah (ﷺ) with my legs between him and the Qibla. When he prostrated himself he pinched me and I drew up my legs, and when be stood up, I stretched them out. She said: At that time there were no lamps in the houses.
question: How did the absence of lamps in early Islamic households affect their daily routines and practices?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said prayer and I (lay) opposite to him while I was in menses. Sometimes his clothes touched me when he prostrated.
question: What are the etiquettes of prayer when in proximity to someone who is menstruating?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said prayer at night and I was by his side in a state of meanses and I had a sheet pulled over me a portion of which was on his side.
question: What considerations are there for a woman in a state of menstruation when her spouse is performing prayers?

hadith-eng: An inquirer asked the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about the prayer in a single garment. He (the Holy Prophet) add: Has everyone of you two garments?
question: What considerations should be made regarding clothing when performing prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira with another chain of transmitters.
question: What role does Abu Huraira play in the transmission of hadiths in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: A person addressed the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and said to him: Can any one of us say prayer in one garment? He said: Do all of you possess two garments?
question: What considerations should be taken into account regarding attire when performing prayers?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: None of you must pray in a single garment of which no part comes over his shoulders.
question: Why is it important to ensure proper clothing during acts of worship in Islam?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying in Umm Salama's house in a single garment, placing its two ends over his shoulders.
question: What can be learned about the simplicity of the Prophet's (ﷺ) attire during prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated by Hisham b. 'Urwa with the same chain of transmitters except (with this difference) that the word mutawashshihan was used and not the word mushtamilan.
question: What is the importance of the chain of transmitters in preserving the accuracy of hadiths?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying prayer in the house of Umm Salama in a single garment with its extremities crossing each other.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of crossing the extremities of a garment while praying?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying in a single garment with its ends crossing each other. 'Isa b. Hammad added:" placing on his shoulders".
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) simplicity in dress during prayer from this narration?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying in a single garment crossing the two ends.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of crossing the ends of a garment during prayer?

hadith-eng: I called upon the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)."
question: What is the importance of direct communication with the Prophet (ﷺ) in the context of hadith narration?

hadith-eng: He saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing like this.
question: What can be learned from the companions' adherence to the Prophet's way of performing prayers?

hadith-eng: I visited the Apostle (ﷺ) and saw him praying on a reed mat on which he was prostrating himself. And I saw him praying in a single garment with ends crossed with each other.
question: What does the use of a single garment during prayer signify in terms of Islamic teachings on modesty and practicality?

hadith-eng: " Placing its (mantle's) ends on his shoulders" ; and the narration transmitted by Abu Bakr and Suwaid (the words are):" the ends crossing with each other".
question: What can variations in hadith narrations tell us about the transmission of Islamic teachings?
